question: Who had founded the Asiatic Society of Bengal in 1784? (UPSC Prelims 1984)
option_1: Lord Clive
option_2: Lord Warren Hastings
option_3: Queen Victoria
option_4: William Jones
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • Sir William Jones, a British lawyer and Orientalist, founded the Asiatic Society of Bengal on January 15, 1784. The society was originally named the “Asiatick Society”.
  • The society was established to encourage Oriental studies. Jones used the society to share his ideas about the importance of Hindu culture and learning, and the role of Sanskrit in the Aryan languages.
  • Jones sent a circular letter to a select group of British residents of Calcutta to establish the society. The meeting to establish the society was presided over by Justice Robert Chambers in Calcutta, which was then the capital of the Presidency of Fort William.

question:
Assertion (A) : In 1946 in Bombay the ratings of the Royal Indian Navy RIN rose in open mutiny against the British.

Reason (R) : The Royal Indian Navy joined the INA................... (UPSC Prelims 1984)
option_1: A and R both are incorrect
option_2: A is correct but R is incorrect
option_3: A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A
option_4: A and R are correct but R is not the correct explanation of A.
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • The Royal Indian Navy (RIN) Mutiny, also known as the Indian Naval Mutiny, began on February 18, 1946, when naval ratings in Bombay (now Mumbai) went on strike.

The mutiny was a result of many factors, including:

1. Discrimination: The British military discriminated against HMIS Talwar’s rating based on race.

2. Salary: Indian and British troops were paid different salaries for the same position.

3. Access: British soldiers had better access to facilities and food.

  • The mutiny was organized secretly by the Marines and the Indian people. The leaders of the mutiny were Salil Shyam, B. C. Dutt, Madan Singh, Rishi Dev Puri (Deb), and M. S. Khan.
  • The mass strike against the British authorities continued until February 23, 1946. In this one week, the city of Bombay stood firmly behind the ratings.
  • The Royal Indian Navy (RIN) was formally inaugurated in 1934 and was divided into the Royal Indian Navy and the Royal Pakistan Navy after India’s partition. On January 26, 1950, India became a republic and the RIN was renamed the Indian Navy.
  • The RIN mutiny, also known as the 1946 Naval Uprising, was a failed insurrection of Indian naval ratings, soldiers, police personnel, and civilians against the British government in India.
  • The mutiny was a widespread and coordinated protest by Indian sailors within the British Indian Navy, symbolizing a major challenge to British colonial rule just before India gained independence in 1947.

question: The first Civil Disobedience was started by Gandhiji after the.............. (UPSC Prelims 1985)
option_1: Rowlatt Act of 1919
option_2: Jallianwala Bagh massacre in 1919
option_3: Chauri Chaura incident in 1922
option_4: Arrival of Cripps’ Mission in 1942
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • The first Civil Disobedience Movement led by Mahatma Gandhi was started in 1919 against the Rowlatt Act. The Rowlatt Act, officially known as the Anarchical and Revolutionary Crimes Act of 1919, was passed by the British government to curb political unrest in India after World War I.
  • It allowed the authorities to imprison any person suspected of revolutionary activities without trial, which was seen as a direct attack on civil liberties. Gandhi considered the Act unjust and oppressive, and in response, he launched a nationwide Satyagraha campaign — marking the beginning of civil disobedience in India, where people peacefully refused to obey unjust laws.

Jallianwala Bagh massacre :

  • It took place in 1919, soon after the Rowlatt Act protests. It was a tragic outcome of the unrest created by the Act when British troops under General Dyer opened fire on a peaceful gathering in Amritsar, killing hundreds. Although this event intensified India’s struggle for freedom, it was not the cause for which the first civil disobedience began.

Chauri Chaura incident :

  • It took place in 1922 during the Non-Cooperation Movement, not the Civil Disobedience Movement. It involved violent clashes between protestors and the police, leading Gandhi to suspend the movement because it violated his principle of nonviolence.

Arrival of Cripps’ Mission :

  • It arrived in 1942 and was related to World War II, when the British government sent Sir Stafford Cripps to negotiate Indian cooperation in the war effort. It came much later and had no link to the first civil disobedience movement.
  • Thus, Gandhi’s first act of Civil Disobedience was launched in 1919 as a protest against the Rowlatt Act, making option (a) the correct answer.

question: Who among the following Governors- General introduced the Dual System of Government? (UPSC Prelims 1985)

option_4: Lord Rippon

The Dual Government system divided the Bengal administration into two parts:

2. Nizamat: The nawab was given ad ministrative rights

The system had both positive and negative outcomes:

Positive outcomes :

1. The British gained control over the region

2. The British were able to exert their rules

Negative outcomes :

1. The system increased complexity and shifted favor from native traders to foreign British traders

2. It also affected the revenue and justice system

3. The company exploited citizens through labor, high taxes, and other atrocities

question: Which of the following Acts gave representation to Indians for the first time in legislatures? (UPSC Prelims 1985)
option_1: The Indian Councils Act. 1909
option_2: The Indian Councils Act, 1919
option_3: The Government of India Act, 1935
option_4: None of the above
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

The Indian Councils Act of 1909 :

  • It is also known as the Morley-Minto reform, is another act that gave representation to Indians for the first time in legislation. This act empowered the Governor General to nominate one Indian member to the Executive Council. The act also granted the Muslim League’s request for separate electorates and reserved seats in the Imperial Council.

The Government of India Act of 1919 :

  • It was a British Parliament act that aimed to increase Indian participation in the administration of their country. The act was based on the recommendations of a report by Edwin Montagu, the Secretary of State for India, and Lord Chelmsford, India’s Viceroy between 1916 and 1921.
  • The act introduced bicameralism and direct elections for the first time in India. The Imperial Legislative Council was converted into a bicameral legislature with the Imperial Legislative Assembly as the lower house and the Council of State as the upper house.
  • The act also gave the Governor-General the power to suspend ministers for any reason he deemed appropriate. The Governor General also retained full control of finances. The Legislative Council could enact legislation, but it required the consent of the Governor. The act also included important issues like law and order, finance, and land revenue in a reserved list.
  • However, the majority of members in the councils were still appointed by the British government rather than being elected by the Indian public. The British government also retained significant control over crucial areas such as defense, finance, and administration.

The Government of India Act of 1935 :

  • It was a milestone in the history of the Government of India. It was the last constitution given to India by the British before the country gained independence in 1947.

The act was based on the following:

1. Simon Commission Report

2. Recommendations of the Round Table Conferences

3. The White Paper published by the British government in 1933

4. Report of the Joint Select Committees

The act’s features include:

1. Federal system: The act established a federal system of the Indian Government.

2. Division of powers: The act divided powers between the center and the states or provinces.

3. Two chambers: The act introduced the concept of having two chambers within the state.

4. Abolition of provincial dyarchy: The act abolished the system of provincial dyarchy and suggested the establishment of dyarchy at the center.

5. Federation of India: The act suggested the establishment of a “Federation of India” consisting of the provinces of British India and most of the princely states.

6. Division of powers into three lists: The act divided the powers between center and units in terms of three lists: federal list, the provincial list and the concurrent list.

  • Tilak is believed to have said the words in 1916 in Belgaum, Karnataka. He was released from prison in 1914 and returned to political life.
  • Tilak popularized four concepts :

2. Swadeshi

3. national education and

question: The partition of Bengal was undertaken with the view of.............. (UPSC Prelims 1985)
option_1: Suppressing the revolt arisen
option_2: Satisfying the Hindus and the Muslims
option_3: Meeting the demand by the Hindus and the Muslims for a separate State
option_4: Dividing the Hindus of the West and the West Bengal and increasing Hindu-Muslim tensions
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • The Partition of Bengal in 1905 was a territorial reorganization of the Bengal Presidency by the British Raj authorities. The partition separated the largely Muslim eastern areas from the largely Hindu western areas.

The reasons cited for the partition include:

1. Administrative convenience

2. Splitting the Bengali population

3. Restricting the influence of the Bengali politicians

4. In response to riots against the policies caused by the Swadeshi movement

5. To foster division

  • The partition was announced on July 16, 1905 by Lord Curzon, the then Viceroy of India. The partition was implemented on October 16, 1905.
  • The partition animated the Muslims to form their own national organization along communal lines. The Swadeshi movement was started in response to the partition in 1905. The movement advocated for the boycott of British goods and the promotion of Indian-made goods, and it played a significant role in the Indian independence movement.

Provincial Autonomy

  • The act introduced the concept of “separate electorate” and increased the size of the legislative councils at the center and the provinces. The act also enhanced the functions of the legislative councils, allowing members to ask supplementary questions, move resolutions on the budget, and vote for separate items for the budget of the country.
  • The act was formulated by John Morley, secretary of state for India (1905–10). With the help of Krishna G. Gupta (Indian Civil Service officer) and Sayyid Husain Bilgrami (member of the Indian Muslim League), John Morley was able to bring a resolution in the British parliament.

The Government of India Act of 1919 :

  • It was a law passed by the British Parliament to increase Indian participation in the government of India. The act was also known as the Councils Act of 1919. It was in effect from 1919 to 1929.
  • The act introduced the concept of responsible government and a federal structure with a unitary bias. It also established a dual system of government, with one accountable government and one not accountable.

The act also introduced:

  1. Bicameralism
  2. Direct elections
  3. The concept of separate electorate
  4. The office of High Commissioner for India in London

The act also included matters related to specific provinces, such as:

  • Public health, Local self-government, Education, General administration, Medical facilities, Land revenue, Water supply, Famine relief, Law and order, Agriculture.

The Government of India Act of 1935 :

  • It was a milestone in the history of theGovernment of India. It was the last constitution given to India by the British before the country gained independence in 1947.

The Act was based on the following :

  • Simon Commission Report Recommendations of the Round Table Conferences T he White Paper published by the British government in 1933 Report of the Joint Select Committees

The Act’s features include:

1. Federal system: The act established a federal system of the Indian Government.

2. Division of powers: The act divided powers between the center and the provinces.

3. Establishment of an all-Indian Federation: The act provided for the establishment of an all-Indian Federation consisting of provinces and princely states as units.

4. Abolition of provincial dyarchy: The act abolished the system of provincial dyarchy and suggested the establishment of dyarchy at the center.

  • The Act was first published on August 2, 1935 and received royal assent in August 1935. It was the longest Act that the British Parliament ever enacted until the Greater London Authority Act 1999 surpassed it.

The Indian Independence Act of 1947 :

  • It was passed by the British Parliament on July 5, 1947 and received royal assent on July 18, 1947. The act granted independence to India and Pakistan on August 15, 1947.

 The act partitioned British India into two new independent dominions:

1. India and

2. Pakistan.

Pakistan was divided into two territories:

  • West Pakistan and East Pakistan, which is now Bangladesh. The act also separated the Muslim, Hindu, and Sikh populations.

The act also:

1. Abolished the title of the “Emperor of India” from the British Crown

2. Abolished the position of the Secretary of States for India and the office of the Viceroy

3. Allowed for a joint Governor-General if both parties agreed

4. Allowed both states’ constituent assemblies to draft constitutions for their own countries

question: Lord Wellesley greatly extended the British dominion in India through............... (UPSC Prelims 1985)
option_1: Doctrine Lapse
option_2: Subsidiary Alliance
option_3: Partitioning of Indian States
option_4: Annexing the princely States
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • Lord Wellesley, the British Governor General of India from 1798 to 1805, expanded the British dominion in India through the Subsidiary Alliance system. This system brought the princely kingdoms under British rule.

The Subsidiary Alliance system required Indian rulers to:

1. Pay a subsidy to the British for the maintenance of the British army

2. Dissolve their own armed forces

3. Accept British forces in their territory

  • In exchange, the British would protect the rulers from their enemies and promised not to interfere in the internal affairs of the allied state. However, they rarely followed through on this promise.
  • Lord Wellesley also relied on war and assuming the territories of formerly subordinated rulers to achieve political control over India.

The Doctrine of Lapse :

  • It was a policy used by the East India Company to annex princely states in the Indian subcontinent. The policy was devised by Lord Dalhousie, the Governor General of India from 1848 to 1856, to deal with questions of succession to Hindu Indian states.
  • The policy was applied until 1858, when the British Raj took over rule from the East India Company. The policy was based on the British belief that they had a moral and legal obligation to modernize and stabilize Indian states.
  • The policy stated that any princely state or territory under the British East India Company would automatically be annexed if the ruler died without a male heir. Satara was the first state annexed under the doctrine of lapse in 1848.
  • The policy was a main political cause for the great revolt of 1857. In 1857, a group of Indian rulers formed a secret society called the “Sepoy Mutiny” to overthrow the East India Company. This uprising was unsuccessful, but it did lead to the end of the doctrine of lapse in 1859.

question: Sepoy mutiny of 1857 failed due to the.............. (UPSC Prelims 1985)
option_1: Lack of effective organisation
option_2: Lack of unity of purpose
option_3: Lack of unified system of leadership
option_4: All of the above
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • The Sepoy Mutiny, also known as the Indian Mutiny, was an uprising against the British East India Company's rule in 1857-58. The rebellion began on May 10, 1857, when sepoys, or Indian soldiers, in the British East India Company's army rebelled in Meerut, a garrison town northeast of Delhi.
  • The rebellion spread to other areas, including Delhi, Agra, Kanpur, and Lucknow, and eventually involved the masses. The rebellion was contained in 1858 when the rebels were defeated in Gwalior on June 20, 1858.

The rebellion had many causes, including:

1. The British East India Company's attempts to develop the Indian economy and legal system

2. The British paramountcy

3. The doctrine of lapse

4. The introduction of a new cartridge for the Enfield rifle, which was wrapped in paper coated in grease to make it easier to load

5. The refusal of Enfield cartridges

  • The British granted amnesty to all rebels not involved in murder on November 1, 1858, but did not declare the hostilities to have officially ended until July 8, 1859. By the end of the rebellion, over 50,000 sepoys had died or been executed, and another 100,000 civilians were killed by British efforts to put down the rebellion.

The 1857 Mutiny failed due to a number of reasons, including:

1. Lack of planning and leadership

2. Lack of unity

3. Poor organization

4. Lack of common ideal

5. Lack of mass support

6. Administrative causes

7. Discontent among sepoys

8. Organizational and military supeñority of the English side.

9. Poor arms and equipment

10. Lack of spirit of nationalism

11. Lack of pan-India participation

12 Lack of all class participation

13. No support from the ruling class

14. The common people lost faith in Indian soldiers.

Other causes include:

1. Rampant corruption in company's administration

2. Complex judicial system

3. The character of British rule imparted a foreign and alien outlook

4. Exclusion of natives from the higher administrative posts

5. Misgovernance

6. Conditions of service in the Company's Army and cantonments increasingly came into conflict

7. The rebels fought with old-fashioned weapons while the British used all modern weapons

8. In many places the people were scared by the cruelty of the rebels.

question: Gandhiji started the Dandi March............... (UPSC Prelims 1985)
option_1: To demonstrate against the policies of British
option_2: To break the salt law
option_3: To boycott foreign goods
option_4: None of the above
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • In 1930, Mahatma Gandhi and other nationalists started the Dandi March, also known as the Salt Satyagraha, to protest the British Raj’s tax on salt.
  • The Salt Act of 1882 gave the British a monopoly on salt production and heavy taxes on it. Gandhi believed it was sinful to tax salt, an essential food item. He marched from Sabarmati to Dandi, a village in Gujarat, India, with followers to protest the tax. The march lasted 24 days, starting on March 12, 1930, and thousands of peopleparticipated.
  • In 2019, the National Salt Satyagraha Memorial opened in Dandi to commemorate the march.

question:
Assertion (A): The First War of Indian Independence started in 1857.

Reason (R): The soldiers refused to use the greased cartridges. (UPSC Prelims 1985)
option_1: If A and R both are correct and R is the correct explanation of A
option_2: If A and R both are correct but R is not the correct explanation of A
option_3: If A is incorrect but R is correct
option_4: If A is correct but R is incorrect
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • The Indian Rebellion of 1857, also known as the First War of Independence, began on May 10, 1857 in Meerut. The rebellion was an uprising against the rule of the British East India Company, which acted as a sovereign power on behalf of the British Crown.
  • The revolt began as a mutiny of sepoys in the company’s army in Meerut, and then spread to other areas, including Delhi, Agra, Kanpur, and Lucknow. The rebellion was unsuccessful in ousting the British from the country.

The causes of the revolt include:

1. Company rule: About two-thirds of the country was under the East India Company’s rule.

2. Land taxes: People were discontent with the land taxes taken by the Brit ish government.

3. Seizure of kingdoms: The British seized many kingdoms and princely states.

4. Desire for freedom: People wanted freedom from foreign rule.

  • The British granted amnesty to all rebels not involved in murder on November 1, 1858, but did not declare the hostilities to have formally ended until July 8, 1859.
  • Mangal Pandey was the first soldier to refuse to use the greased cartridges of thenew Enfield rifles in March 1857. Pandey was a sepoy in the 34th Bengal Native Infantry regiment of the British East India Company.
  • Pandey’s attack on British officers on March 29, 1857, was the first major incident of what came to be known as the Sepoy Mutiny. Pandey was hanged to death for attacking his officers in Barrackpore, on 29 March 1857.
  • The soldiers refused to use the cartridges because they were believed to be greased with animal fat that was offensive to Hindus and Muslims. The cartridges were made in England and were carried by the sepoys from 1855 to 1857 to check whether they could resist Indian weather.

question: ‘Go back to the Vedas’ was the motto of............... (UPSC Prelims 1986)

option_2: Raja Ram Mohan Roy
option_3: Swami Dayanand Saraswati

He believed that the Vedas contained religious truths and fundamental knowledge relevant to society.He also believed that the Vedas contained messages of equality, parity, and reform.
  • Saraswati’s slogan was intended to connect society with its roots. He believed that this would help abolish untouchability and idol worship, and instill the belief in people that there is only one God. Saraswati was born in Gujarat in 1824, and is sometimes called the “Martin Luther of India”.
  • Some of his major works include Satyarth Prakash, Satyarth Bhumika, Sanskarvidhi, Rigvedadi Bhashya Bhumika, Rigved Bhashyam, and Yajurved Bhashyam. He also founded the Paropakarini Sabha in Ajmer to publish and preach his works and Vedic texts.

question:
Arrange the following in a chronological order............. (UPSC Prelims 1986)

1. Foundation of Muslim League

2. Jallianwala Bagh Massacre

3. Khilafat Movement

4. Civil Disobedience Movement

The correct order is :
option_1: 1, 3, 2, 4
option_2: 1, 2, 3, 4
option_3: 4, 2, 1, 3
option_4: 2, 4, 1, 3
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

The All-India Muslim League (AIML) :

  • It was established on December 30, 1906, in Dhaka. The league was created to represent the interests of Indian Muslims in a country made up of mostly Hindus. The league was an important topic in the Indian struggle for independence.
  • The league led the movement for a separate Muslim nation during the partition of British India in 1947. The Two-Nation theory argued for a different state for the Muslims of the British Indian Empire. This interpretation promised a democratic state where Muslims and non-Muslims would be treated equally. The league was initially encouraged by the British, who were generally favorable to their rule.

The Jallianwala Bagh massacre :

  • It is also known as the Amritsar massacre, took place on April 13, 1919. The massacre was a turning point in India’s independence struggle. On that day, a large group of peaceful protesters gathered in Jallianwala Bagh, a public garden in Amritsar, Punjab, India.
  • The protesters were celebrating Baisakhi and wanted to protest the arrest and deportation of two national leaders, Satyapal and Saifuddin Kitchlew. General Reginald Dyer ordered British Indian Army soldiers to fire on the unarmed civilians. The soldiers fired for about ten minutes, killing an estimated 379 people and injuring more than a thousand. The victims included men, women, and children. The incident led to widespread condemnation, with Winston Churchill describing the day as “monstrous”.

The Khilafat Movement :

  • It was a political campaign that took place from 1919–1924.It was a protest by Indian Muslims against British policies towards Turkey and the Ottoman Empire after World War I. The movement’s goal was to pressure the British government to keep the Ottoman Sultan as Caliph of Islam after the Ottoman Empire’s breakup.
  • The movement also aimed to unite the Muslim community in India behind the broader Indian nationalist movement. It sought to address Turkey’s grievances and promote Hindu-Muslim unity.
  • The movement was abruptly called off on February 12, 1922, at Gandhiji’s insistence, following the news of the Chauri Chaura incident.

The Civil Disobedience Movement (CDM) :

  • It was a significant event in India’s fight for independence from British rule in 1930. The movement originated in Calcutta (present-day Kolkata) and spread throughout Bengal.
  • Civil disobedience is when a citizen refuses to obey certain laws, demands, orders,or commands of a government. Some definitions say that civil disobedience must be nonviolent to be considered “civil”.
  • The CDM was a direct-action campaign of tax resistance and nonviolent protest against the British salt monopoly. It was led by Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi and originated with the Dandi March, also known as the Salt March and the Dandi Satyagraha.

Gandhi made 11 demands to the British government, including:

  1.  Releasing political prisoners
  2. Accepting the Postal
  3. Reservation Bill
  4. Reducing the rupee-sterling exchange ratio
  5. Introducing textile protection
  6. Reserving coastal shipping for Indians
  7. Reducing land revenue by 50%
  • The British did not respond to Gandhi’s demands, and the CDM was withdrawn in 1931 when Gandhi signed the “Gandhi Irwin” pact.

Some reasons that paved the way for the CDM include:

  1. The formation of the Simon Commission
  2. The rejection of the demand for Dominion Status
  3. Demonstrations against the detention of social revolutionaries

Some examples of civil disobedience movements:

  1. Salt March
  2. Khilafat movement : This mass civil disobedience movement included the non-payment of taxes and the establishment of national schools and colleges.
  3. The Karachi session : This landmark session was held in 1931, immediately after the Gandhi-Irwin pact. It brought to an end the first phase of the civil disobedience movement that had begun with the Dandi March.

question:
Which of the following statements is true about Annie Besant? (UPSC Prelims 1986)

1. She was the President of Indian National Congress

2. She was the founder of the Asiatic Society

3. She was the founder of the Theosophical Society

Codes:
option_1: 1 and 2
option_2: 1 and 3
option_3: 1 only
option_4: 1, 2 and 3
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • Annie Besant became the first woman president of the Indian National Congress (INC) in 1917. She was a British citizen, a socialist, women’s rights activist, author, and politician.
  • Besant was a strong supporter of the Indian self-government movement and contributed to many social reforms in India. In 1916, she launched the Home Rule League with Lokmanya Tilak to campaign for democracy in India and dominion status within the Empire. She also co-founded the Banaras Hindu University.
  • Besant was also a political and religious activist with feminist ideas. She fought for the freedom of thought, secularism, women’s right, birth control, workers right and Fabian socialism.
  • Sir William Jones, a British lawyer and Orientalist, founded the Asiatic Society of Bengal on January 15, 1784. The society’s main focus was to study Hindu culture and philosophy, and to examine the importance of the Sanskrit language.
  • The Asiatic Society is located at Park Street, Kolkata, West Bengal, India. It includes a library, museum, and the Journal of the Asiatic Society.
  • The Theosophical Society was founded in New York City in 1875 by Helena Petrovna Blavatsky, Colonel Henry Steel Olcott, William Quan Judge, and 16 others. The society’s headquarters were established in Adyar, India in 1882.
  • The society’s main objectives were to promote the study of ancient religions and philosophies and to form a universal brotherhood of man without distinction of race, color, or creed.
  • In 1893, Mrs. Annie Besant took over the leadership of the Society after the death of Olcott. The movement was popularized by Annie Besant in India.

question:
Arrange the following in a chronological order: (UPSC Prelims 1986)

1. Dandi March

2. Simon Commission

3. Poona Pact

4. Gandhi Irwin Pact

The correct order is :
option_1: 1, 2, 3, 4
option_2: 3, 2, 1, 4
option_3: 2, 1, 4, 3
option_4: 3, 4, 1, 2
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

The Simon Commission :

  • It is also known as the Indian Statutory Commission, was a group of seven British Parliament members who studied constitutional reform in India in 1927. The commission was appointed by the British Conservative government in November 1927 to report on the working of the Indian constitution. The commission’s chairman was Sir John Simon.
  • The Simon Commission’s recommendations included giving more autonomy to Indian provincial governments, but keeping a veto for the Viceroy. The Simon Report was important in the constitutional discussion that led to the Government of India Act of 1935.
  • The commission was boycotted by Indians because all its members were Englishmen and the commission had no Indian member. The slogan “Simon Go Back” became one of the most enduring slogans of the Indian freedom struggle.

The Dandi March :

  • It is also known as the Salt March, was a nonviolent civil disobedience campaign led by Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi from March 12, 1930 to April 6, 1930.
  • The march was a protest against the British salt monopoly, which was established by the 1882 Salt Act. The act gave the British a monopoly on the collection and manufacture of salt, and levied a tax on it.
  • Gandhi and other nationalists believed that taxing salt was sinful because it is a basic food item. The march was a centerpiece of the 1930 Salt Satyagraha, which was a protest against the increasingly repressive salt tax.
  • The march began with a core group of followers, and hundreds more joined them along the way. On April 5, the group reached Dandi after a 240-mile (385 km) journey.
  • Gandhi was arrested in early May after informing the British governor of India of his intention to march on the Dharasana saltworks. News of Gandhi’s imprisonment led tens of thousands more Indians to join the satyagraha.
  • The Dandi March and Gandhi’s satyagraha teachings had a significant influence on American activists like Martin Luther King Jr. and James Bevel during the Civil Rights Movement in the 1960s.

The Gandhi-Irwin Pact :

  • It was a political agreement signed on March 5, 1931 between Mahatma Gandhi and Lord Irwin, the Viceroy of India.
  • The pact marked the end of a period of civil disobedience, or satyagraha, in India against British rule. The pact aimed to resolve the civil disobedience movement and ease political tensions in India.

Some of the demands made in the pact include:

  1. Withdrawing all ordinances and prosecutions
  2. Releasing all political prisoners
  3. Restoring the confiscated properties of the satyagrahis
  4. Permitting the free collection or manufacture of salt
  • In the pact, Gandhi promises to discontinue the Satyagraha Campaign and Irwin promises to release those Indians arrested for salt production.

The Poona Pact :

  • It was an agreement signed in 1932 between Mahatma Gandhi and Dr. B.R. Ambedkar. The pact was signed in Yerwada Central Jail, Poona, on September 24, 1932. 
  • The pact was a negotiated settlement that significantly shaped the political representation of the depressed classes, now known as Scheduled Castes (SC).

The pact’s terms included:

  1. Guaranteed fair representation of the depressed classes in public services
  2. Reserved 147 seats for the depressed classes in the legislature
  3. Earmarked a portion of the educational grant for the depressed classes
  4. Accepted a joint electorate
  • Abandoned the principle of a separate electorate
  • The pact also gave reserved seats for depressed classes in the central and provincial legislative councils.
  • The pact was significant because it stopped Mahatma Gandhi’s fast-unto-death action. Gandhi did not want to slow down the process of integrating Dalits. The pact marked the start of the movement against “untouchability” within the Indian nationalist movement.

question:

question: Which of the following Acts was introduced by the Britishers to remove the shortcomings of the Regulating Act? (UPSC Prelims 1986)
option_1: Pitt’s India Act, 1784
option_2: Rowlatt Act
option_3: The Charter Act of 1793
option_4: Government of India Act 1919
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • Pitt’s India Act 1784 or the East India Company Act 1784 was passed in the British Parliament to rectify the defects of the Regulating Act 1773.

The Pitt’s India Act of 1784 :

  • It is also known as the East India Company Act of 1784, was a British Parliament act that established a dual system of control over British India. The act was named after British prime minister William Pittthe Younger and was intended to address the shortcomings of the Regulating Act of 1773.
  • The act established the British government’s authority over the East India Company’s rule in India. The act also distinguished between the company’s commercial and political functions. The act was in effect until 1858.

Some other outcomes of the Pitt’s India Act:

1. Governor-General :

  • The act reduced the number of members required in the Governor-General’s council. The Governor-General also gained veto power and lost their military powers.

2. Board of Control :

  • The act established a Board of Control to manage the Company’s civil, military, and revenue affairs. The Board of Control included the chancellor of exchequer and a secretary of state.

3. Property disclosure :

  • The act required civil and military officers to disclose their properties in India and Britain within two months of joining. Corrupt officers faced severe punishments.

4. Capital :

  • The act made Calcutta the capital of the British Indian colonies.

5. Subservience :

  • The act made the Madras and Bombay presidencies subservient to the Bengal Presidency.

6. The Charter Act of 1793 :

  • This Act continued the company’s rule over the British territories in India. It continued the company’s trade monopoly in India for another 20 years.
  • The Act established that “acquisition of sovereignty by the subjects of the Crown is on behalf of the Crown and not in its own right,” which clearly stated that the company’s political functions were on behalf of the British government. The company’s dividends were allowed to be raised to 10%.
  • The Governor-General was given more powers. He could override his council’s decision under certain circumstances.
  • He was also given authority over the governors of Madras and Bombay.
  • When the Governor-General was present in Madras or Bombay, he would supersede in authority over the governors of Madras and Bombay.
  • In the Governor-General’s absence from Bengal, he could appoint a Vice President from among the civilian members of his Council.
  • The composition of the Board of Control changed. It was to have a President and two junior members, who were not necessarily members of the Privy Council.
  • The salaries of the staff and the Board of Control were also now charged to the company.
  • After all expenses, the company had to pay the British government Rs.5 Lakhs from the Indian revenue annually.
  • Senior company officials were barred from leaving India without permission. If they did so, it would be considered as a resignation.
  • The company was granted the authority to grant licenses to individuals and company employees to carry on trade in India. This was known as ‘privilege’ or ‘country trade’. This led to shipments of opium to China.
  • This Act separated the revenue administration and the judiciary functions of the company leading to the disappearance of Maal Adalats (revenue courts).

  • The act was the first step taken by the British government to control and regulate the affairs of the East India Company in India. It acknowledged the company’s political and administrative functions for the first time.

The act’s provisions included:

1. Requiring the company’s court of directors to report to the British government on revenue, civil, and military affairs in India.

2. Limiting the court of directors’ tenure to four years.

  • The act was introduced to address the company’s misgovernance, which had led to bankruptcy in the country.
  • The Regulating Act and the India Act (1784) established government control of political policy.
  • The company’s commercial monopoly was broken in 1813, and from 1834 it was merely a managing agency for the British government of India. It lost that role after the Indian Mutiny (1857).

The Partition of Bengal in 1905 :

  • It was a territorial reorganization of the Bengal Presidency by the British Raj. Thepartition separated the largely Muslim eastern areas from the largely Hindu western areas.
  • The partition was announced by Lord Curzon, the Viceroy of India at the time, and came into effect during his viceroyalty.
  • The partition left a significant minority of Hindus in East Bengal and Muslims in West Bengal. The Muslims supported the partition because they would have their own province, but the Hindus opposed it.
  • The partition marked the start of the Indian National Congress’ transformation from a middle-class political organization into a wide-ranging growing movement. The partition brought the province to the brink of open rebellion. British officials argued that the province’s size made it difficult to handle and led to the marginalization of the poorer eastern part.

The All-India Muslim League (AIML) :

  • It was established on December 30, 1906, in Dhaka. The league was created to represent the interests of Indian Muslims in a country made up of mostly Hindus.
  • The league was an important topic in the Indian struggle for independence.
  • The league led the movement for a separate Muslim nation during the partition of British India in 1947.
  • The Two-Nation theory argued for a different state for the Muslims of the British Indian Empire. This interpretation promised a democratic state where Muslims and non-Muslims would be treated equally.
  • The league was initially encouraged by the British, who were generally favorable to their rule.

The Surat Split :

 It was a 1907 event when the Indian National Congress (INC) split into two groups:

1. the Moderates and

2. the Radicals, also known as the Extremists.

  • The split was caused by a disagreement over who should be the presidential candidate. The Extremists wanted Lala Lajpat Rai, while the Moderates supported Rash Bihari Ghosh. The split was a major blow to the INC, and the differences between the two groups presented an opportunity to the British.
  • The INC reunited in 1915. The Moderates, also known as the Early Nationalists, were a group of political leaders active between 1885 and 1907. They believed that political connections with Britain were in India’s best interests and that the time wasn’t right for a direct challenge to British rule.
  • The Extremists believed in self-reliance as a weapon against domination. They promoted Swadeshi and boycotted foreign goods.

question:
What is the correct chronological order of the following? (UPSC Prelims 1987)

A. Cabinet Mission

B. Montague Chelmsford Reforms

C. Minto – Morley Reforms

D. Cripps Mission

Codes:
option_1: C, B, D, A
option_2: A, B, C, D
option_3: B, C, D, A
option_4: D, A, B, C
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

The Morley-Minto Reforms :

  • It is also known as the Indian Councils Act of 1909, were a series of reforms passed by the British Parliament in 1909.
  • The reforms were formulated by John Morley, the secretary of state for India from 1905–1910, following discussions with Lord Minto, the viceroy of India from 1905–1910.
  • The reforms introduced the elective principle to membership in the imperial and local legislative councils in India.

The reforms also increased the size of the legislative councils at the center and the provinces:

1. Central Legislative Council: From 16 to 60 members.

2. Legislative Councils of Bengal, Madras, Bombay and United Provinces: 50 members each.

3. Legislative Councils of Punjab, Burma and Assam: 30 members each.

  • The reforms also included the admission of Indians to the Secretary of State’s council, to the viceroy’s executive council, and to the executive councils of Bombay and Madras. The reforms also introduced an elected element into legislative councils with provision for separate electorates for Muslims.
  • The reforms were aimed at appeasing the moderates of the country. Although it did not go far enough in giving Indians a voice in their own country, it was a significant improvement on previous legislation and opened up new opportunities for Indian participation in politics.

The Montagu-Chelmsford Reforms of 1919 :

  • It were a set of constitutional reforms introduced by the British colonial government to gradually establish self governing institutions in India.
  • The reforms were also known as the Mont–Ford Reforms.
  • The reforms were based on the recommendations of a report by Edwin Montagu, the Secretary of State for India, and Lord Chelmsford, the Viceroy of India from 1916–1921.

The reforms included:

1. Granting voting rights to women over the age of 21

2. A royal amnesty for political prisoners and revolutionary terrorists

3. The Rowlatt Act, which suspended basic principles of rule of law and allowed closed court proceedings against suspected political dissidents

  • The reforms were a turning point in India’s constitutional evolution and its struggle for independence. However, the reforms did not satisfy the demands of Indian nationalists.

The Cripps Mission :

  • It was a meeting between British government representatives and Indian leaders that took place from March 22 to April 11, 1942.
  • The mission’s purpose was to secure Indian cooperation and support for the British war efforts in World War II. The mission’s proposals were constitutional and sought Indian support.
  • The mission was organized by Sir Richard Stafford Cripps, a member of the War Cabinet. The mission failed and the issue of India’s constitution was postponed until the end of the war.
  • The mission’s failure led to the Quit India Movement, a countrywide strike wave that involved workers, peasants, and states’ peoples.

The mission’s proposals included:

1. Establishing the Indian Union

2. Allowing India to participate in international bodies and the United Nations

3. The Constituent Assembly would have members nominated by the Provincial Assemblies as well as the Princely States

4. Any Province, which is not prepared to accept the new Constitution would have the right to sign a separate agreement with Britain regarding its future status.

  • The Muslim League criticized the idea of a single Indian Union. They also stated that the proposals denied the Muslims the right to self-determination and the creation of Pakistan.

The Cabinet Mission Plan :

  • It was a proposal put forward by the British Cabinet Mission in 1946 to address the issue of Indian independence. It recommended the creation of a united India with a federal structure, granting significant autonomy to provinces, while ensuring protections for minorities.
  • However, it failed to gain acceptance from Indian political leaders and ultimately led to the partition of India and the creation of Pakistan.

question: Lord Cornwallis introduced............ (UPSC Prelims 1987)
option_1: Zamindari system
option_2: Mahalwari system
option_3: Mansabdari system
option_4: None of the above
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • In 1793, Lord Cornwallis introduced the Permanent Settlement Act, also known as the Zamindari system, in Bengal, Bihar, Orissa, and Varanasi.
  • The Permanent Settlement is an agreement between the East India Company and the Zamindars to fix land revenue.

The system’s main features are:

1. Zamindars, or landlords, are made the owners of the land

2. Farmers are reduced to the status of tenants

3. The land rights of members are fixed in perpetuity

4. There is no provision for fixed rent or occupancy right for actual cultivators

  • The Permanent Settlement was introduced to generate revenue for the East India Company and encourage the zamindars to invest in improving the land. Cornwallis was a British Army officer, Whig politician, and colonial administrator.
  • He is best known as one of the leading British general officers in the American War of Independence.

The Mahalwari system :

  • It was a revenue system used by the British in India. It was introduced in 1822 by Holt Mackenzie and Robert Merttins Bird.
  • The word “Mahalwari” comes from the Hindi word “Mahal”, which means a group of villages.
  • In the Mahalwari system, village headmen collect land revenue from farmers on behalf of the entire village.
  • The revenue is based on the produce of the Mahal, which is a compact area containing one or more villages. In this system, landlords or Lambardars are assigned to represent villages or groups of villages. The landlords and village communities are jointly responsible for paying taxes.
  • The Mahalwari system had elements from both the Zamindari and Ryotwari systems. It was prevalent in parts of the Gangetic Valley, Uttar Pradesh, the North Western province, parts of Central India, and Punjab.
  • One of the system’s flaws is that the survey is based on erroneous assumptions, which allows for manipulation and corruption. The Company spends more on collection than the revenue it receives at times, and as a result, the system is deemed a failure.

The Mansabdari system :

  • It was a grading system used by the Mughal Empire to rank and salary Mansabdars, or nobles, in 1571. The word “Mansab” comes from the Arabic language and means “position” or “rank”. The system included all aspects of administration, including civil, military, and revenue affairs.

It had two main features:

1. Zat: The personal rank of the official, which indicated their pay and status

2. Sawar: The rank that determined how many horses an official was required to maintain

  • The system determined the rank and status of a government official and military generals. Every civil and military officer was given a mansab, which determined their salaries and allowances.
  • The system also provided the emperor with a loyal and professional class of officers who were directly accountable to thecentral authority. It facilitated the efficient mobilization of the military by attaching a specific number of soldiers to each mansabdar.

question: Which one of the following was the most immediate factor for the spread of Swadeshi and Boycott agitation during the first decade of the present century? (UPSC Prelims 1988)

solution_text:

  • The Indian Councils Act of 1909 introduced the concept of separate electorates. The British granted separate electorates to Muslims in 1909, after a Muslim delegation requested them in 1906.
  • The Act was expanded in 1919 to allow Muslims to elect their own representatives in designated constituencies. Under separate electorates, Muslim members were to be elected only by Muslim voters.
  • The Act of 1909 also increased the size of legislative councils at the Centre and the provinces. Lord Minto is known as the father of the communal electorate.

The Government of India Act of 1919 :

  • It is also known as the Montague Chelmsford Reforms, introduced dyarchy in India. The act came into force in 1921. Dyarchy is a system of double government, which means rule of two.

The act divided provincial subjects into two categories:

1. transferred and

2. reserved: Transferred

3. subjects : The governor, with the help of ministers, administers these subjects. These subjects are responsible to the Legislative Council.

4. Reserved subjects : The governor and his executive council administer these subjects, and they are not responsible to the Legislative Council.

  • The governor-general has complete jurisdiction over the provinces’ reserved issues. The act also introduced bicameralism and direct election for the first time in India, and established a public service commission in 1926.

The Government of India Act of 1935 :

  • It introduced provincial autonomy in India. The act gave more autonomy to the provinces, abolished diarchy at the provincial levels, and established an All India Federation. Provincial autonomy is the degree of self governance and decision-making power granted to provinces or regional entities within a country. The act originally received royal assent in August 1935.
  • The British colonial government then revised and adapted its entire body of central and provincial administrative laws to ensure that they conformed to the principle of provincial autonomy between 1935 and 1938.
  • The Cripps Mission, a failed attempt by the British government in 1942, proposed a Constituent Assembly to frame a new constitution for India: The Constituent Assembly would be a body to make a constitution for India after the war.
  • The members would be elected by the provincial assemblies and nominated by the rulers in the case of the Princely States. The constitution would be drafted entirely by Indians.
  • The proposed Constituent Assembly would consist of 292 members from British India and 93 from Indian States. Any province unwilling to join the Indian dominion could form a separate union and have a separate constitution.
  • Any province which wouldn’t accept the new constitution would have the right to sign a separate agreement with the British.
  • Indian Provinces were given the right of secession from the Centre after 10 years. Until the new constitution came into force, India’s defence would be controlled by the British and the powers of the Governor General would remain unaltered.

question:
Assertion (A): The Zamindari Settlement was introduced by Lord Cornwallis.

Reason (R): The British desired to create a landed class in India for support. (UPSC Prelims 1988)
option_1: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
option_2: Both A and R are true but R is NOT a correct explanation of A
option_3: A is true but R is false
option_4: A is false but R is true
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • Lord Cornwallis introduced the Zamindari System in 1793 through the Permanent Settlement Act. The system was introduced in the provinces of Bengal, Bihar, Orissa, and Varanasi.

 The Zamindari System is a major land revenue system that consists of three components:

1. the British

2. the Zamindar (Landlord) and

3. the peasants

  • The main feature of the system is that the British Raj receives a fixed sum of land revenue. This revenue is collected from the peasants and then offered to the British Raj.
  • The Zamindari System fixed the land rights of the members in perpetuity without any provision for fixed rent or occupancy right for actual cultivators.
  • Zamindars were recognized as the owners of the lands. The British introduced land settlements in India to create a landed class that would support British authority.
  • The British wanted a regular source of revenue for the state, and settled peasants were easier to control and administer than people who were always on the move.

The Permanent Settlement of 1793 divided the East India Company’s service personnel into three branches:

1. revenue

2. judicial and

3. commercial.

  • Revenues were collected by zamindars, native Indians who were treated as landowners. This division created an Indian landed class that supported British authority.
  • The British were particularly interested in the Indian textile industry, which was one of the most productive in the world at the time.

question:
Consider the following sessions of the Indian National Congress : (UPSC Prelims 1990)

The session in which.............. 

1. The Muslim League and the Indian National Congress met jointly

2. The Indian National Congress divided into two groups.

3. The resolution for “Complete Independence” was passed.

4. The Non-cooperation resolution was passed.

The correct chronological sequence of these sessions is :
option_1: 3-4-1-2
option_2: 2-1-4-3
option_3: 2-3-4-1
option_4: 1-2-3-4
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

The Indian National Congress (INC) split into two groups in 1907:

1. Radicals : Also known as “jahal”, they wanted to use violent methods to expel the British Empire from India.

2. Moderates : Also known as “maval”, they wanted to use non-violent means to achieve Indian independence. The split occurred after the introduction of revolutionary ideas.

  • The two factions had previously patched their differences, but split for good in 1907.
  • The INC reunited in 1915.
  • The INC was founded in 1885, initially with the goal of pursuing moderate reform under the British raj in India. Its roots are in the early Indian nationalist movement that arose from the Indian Rebellion of 1857.
  • The Indian National Congress (INC) and the All-India Muslim League met jointly in 1916 to sign the Lucknow Pact. The pact was masterminded by Muhammad Ali Jinnah, a member of both parties.

The pact’s goals included:

1. Pressuring the British government to adopt a more liberal approach to India

2. Giving Indians more authority to run their country

3. Safeguarding basic Muslim demands

The pact was important because it:

1. Enhanced the League’s power in Indian politics

2. Established communalism as an unavoidable part of Indian politics

3. Gave the impression of Hindu Muslim unity in the national political scene

  • The Muslim League played a decisive role in the 1940s, becoming a driving force behind the division of India along religious lines and the creation of Pakistan as a Muslim state in 1947.
  • The Indian National Congress (INC) passed the Non-Cooperation resolution in December 1920 at its Nagpur session in Maharashtra.
  • The resolution was drafted by Mahatma Gandhi. The resolution stated that “there can be no contentment in India… without the establishment of swarajya”.
  • The INC called upon different sections of society to make sacrifices to attain swarajya, or self-government, by peaceful means. The resolution also promoted self-reliance by spinning khadi, buying Indian-made goods only, and boycotting British goods.
  • The movement also called for stopping planned dismemberment of Turkey (Khilafat Movement) and the end to untouchability.
  • The Indian National Congress (INC) passed the resolution for “complete independence” on December 19, 1929 at the Lahore Session. The resolution is called the Declaration of Purna Swaraj, which means “total independence”.
  • The resolution was made public on January 26, 1930, and the Congress Party urged Indians to celebrate it as “Independence Day”.
  • The resolution was a defining moment in India’s struggle for freedom and set the stage for the subsequent Civil Disobedience movement led by Mahatma Gandhi.
  • The resolution also asked all members of the legislature to resign their seats.

Initially, he was associated with the Adi Brahmo Samaj under Debendranath Tagore but later formed his own branch called the Sadharan Brahma Samaj in 1878, after ideological differences with Tagore. He worked to modernize Indian society by promoting women’s education, widow remarriage, and the abolition of caste distinctions. Hence, Kesab Chandra Sen is correctly matched with Sadharan Brahma Samaj (3).
  • Henry Vivian Derozio was an Anglo-Indian teacher, poet, and radical thinker who founded the Young Bengal Movement in the early 19th century. As a teacher at Hindu College in Calcutta, he inspired his students to question superstitions, challenge social norms, and advocate for rationalism and freedom of thought. His followers, known as “Derozians,” carried forward his reformist and intellectual ideas. Thus, Derozio is rightly matched with the Young Bengal Movement (1).
  • Dadoba Pandurang Tarkhadkar was a pioneer social reformer from Maharashtra who founded the Param Hansa Mandali in 1849 at Bombay (Mumbai). It was one of the earliest socio-religious reform organizations in western India and aimed to promote equality, women’s education, and the rejection of caste-based discrimination and idol worship. Therefore, Dadoba Pandurang is correctly associated with Param Hansa Mandali (2).
  • Devendranath Tagore, father of the famous poet Rabindranath Tagore, was an important reformer and religious thinker who played a major role in the Brahmo Samaj movement. In 1839, he founded the Tatvabodhini Sabha, which aimed to promote the teachings of the Upanishads and reform Hindu society through rational and spiritual awakening. The Sabha later merged with the Brahmo Samaj, strengthening the reformist movement. Hence, Devendranath Tagore correctly matches with Tatvabodhini Sabha (4).

Thus the correct answer is D.

question:
Consider the following events : (UPSC Prelims 1990)

1. Hunter Commission

2. Charles Wood’s Dispatch

3. Sadler Commission

4. Raleigh Commission

Their correct chronological sequence :
option_1: 3-2-1-4
option_2: 2-1-4-3
option_3: 1-4-3-2
option_4: 4-3-2-1
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • Wood’s Dispatch is the informal name for a formal dispatch sent in 1854 by Sir Charles Wood to Lord Dalhousie, the Governor General of India. Wood was the President of the Board of Control of the British East India Company.
  • The dispatch is also known as the Magna Carta of English Education in India. It outlined a plan for expanding education in British India.

The dispatch’s objectives included:

1. Educating Indians on Western culture

2. Producing a class of public officials

3. Promoting the moral and intellectual development of the next generation

4. Enhancing Indians’ practical and vocational skills

The dispatch suggested that:

1. Primary schools should adopt vernacular languages

2. High schools should use an Anglo vernacular medium

3. English should be the medium for college-level education

The dispatch’s recommendations included:

1. Establishing a Department of Public Instruction in each of Bengal’s five provinces

2. Expanding mass education

3. Establishing universities in the three Presidency towns of Calcutta, Bombay, and Madras

The dispatch’s impact included:

1. The establishment of universities in Bombay, Madras, and Calcutta in 1857

2. The establishment of education departments in all provinces

3. The establishment of Bethune School for women’s education

The Hunter Commission :

  • It was established in 1882 by Viceroy Lord Ripon to examine the state of education in India and recommend reforms.

The commission’s objectives were to:

1. Assess the status of elementary education in the British territories

2. Suggest ways to improve and extend elementary education

3. Assess the work of religious missionaries in the field of education

4. The commission was headed by William Wilson Hunter, an Indian Civil Service (ICS) officer and a member of Lord Ripon’s Executive council.

  • The commission had 20 members, including 7 Indian members. The commission tried to improve the Indian education system by developing proper infrastructure, improving primary education, and adopting a policy of religious neutrality.
  • The commission also praised the quality of secondary level education provided in the British occupied areas, particularly the region of Bengal.

The Raleigh Commission : 

  • It is also known as the Indian Universities Commission, was established in 1902 to examine the state of Indian universities and recommend ways to improve their structure and operations. The commission was led by Sir Thomas Raleigh and appointed by Lord Curzon.

The commission’s recommendations included:

1. The government should appoint the majority of university fellows

2. The number and terms of office of fellows should be reduced

3. The government should have the power to change or approve regulations, and to veto university senate regulations

  • The commission also made recommendations for school education reform, university curricular reforms, education and examinations, research, student welfare, and state scholarships.
  • The Sadler Commission was a commission established in 1917 by the Indian government to investigate the problems faced by Calcutta University.

The commission’s goals included:

1. Reducing the load on university education

2. Improving the quality of education

3. Improving the quality of secondary education

4. Freeing universities from the responsibility of secondary education so they can concentrate only on higher education

The commission’s main recommendations included:

1. Organizing all the teaching staff in Calcutta so that Calcutta University would be a full-fledged university

2. Bifurcating higher education at the intermediate examination instead of the matriculation examination

3. Creating intermediate colleges that would offer instruction in arts, science, medicine, engineering, teaching, and more

4. Setting up a separate board of secondary and ‘intermediate education for administration and control of secondary and intermediate education

  •  There should be less rigidity in framing university regulations

question:
Consider the following events in Indian Freedom Movement : (UPSC Prelims 1990)

1. Singh Sabha Movement

2. Quit India Movement

3. Dandi March

4. Gurdwara Reform Movement

The correct chronological sequence of these events is :
option_1: 1-4-3-2
option_2: 4-1-2-3
option_3: 2-3-4-1
option_4: 3-2-1-4
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

The Singh Sabha Movement :

  • It is also known as the Singh Sabha Lehar, was a Sikh movement that began in the 1870s. The movement’s goal was to revive Sikh doctrine and bring back Sikhs who had converted to other religions. The movement also sought to establish a distinct space for Sikhs within India’s religious framework.
  • The movement’s first unit was formed in Amritsar in 1873. A more radical branch was formed in Lahore, which emphasized that Sikhs were not Hindus. The movement was a response to the activities of Christian, Hindu, and Muslim reform movements.
  • The movement’s policy was to avoid criticism of other religions and political matters. The movement also worked to spread Gurmukhi Punjabi through magazines and other media.

The Gurdwara Reform Movement :

  • It is also known as the Akali Movement, was a mass movement that took place from 1920 to 1925. The movement was a campaign to reform Sikh places of worship, known as gurdwaras, in India.
  • The movement began in Amritsar, Punjab, as a protest against the British government and their loyal mahants (priests). The mahants had taken over some of the Sikhs’ gurdwaras.

The movement included:

1. Taran Taran Morcha: A mandate was issued from the Akal Takhat to elect a representative body to govern the Golden Temple and reform other shrines.

2. Nankana tragedy: Nankana Sahib, the birthplace of Guru Nanak, was controlled by Mahants who deprived the poor peasantry of their rights.

3. Morcha Chabian: A campaign to re cover the keys to the Golden Temple treasury.

The Babbar Akali movement :

  • It was a splinter group of “militant” Sikhs who broke away from the mainstream Akali movement in 1921. The Babbar Akali movement was founded by Kishan Singh Gargaj (1886-1926).

The Dandi March :

  • It is also known as the Salt March, was a nonviolent civil disobedience campaign led by Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi from March 12, 1930 to April 6, 1930.
  • The march was a protest against the British salt monopoly, which was established by the 1882 Salt Act. The act gave the British a monopoly on the collection and manufacture of salt, and levied a tax on it.
  • Gandhi and other nationalists believed that taxing salt was sinful because it is a basic food item. The march was a centerpiece of the 1930 Salt Satyagraha, which was a protest against the increasingly repressive salt tax.
  • The march began with a core group of followers, and hundreds more joined them along the way. On April 5, the group reached Dandi after a 240-mile (385 km) journey.
  • Gandhi was arrested in early May after informing the British governor of India of his intention to march on the Dharasana saltworks. News of Gandhi’s imprisonment led tens of thousands more Indians to join the satyagraha.
  • The Dandi March and Gandhi’s satyagraha teachings had a significant influence on American activists like Martin Luther King Jr. and James Bevel during the Civil Rights Movement in the 1960s.

The Quit India Movement :

  • It was a civil disobedience movement launched by Mahatma Gandhi on August 8, 1942. The movement’s demands were to end British rule in India, gain Indian cooperation in World War II, and form a provisional government after the British withdrew.

The movement had two phases:

1. First phase: Urban revolt, marked by strikes, boycotts, and picketing

2. Second phase: Focus shifted to the countryside, which witnessed a major peasant rebellion

  • The movement also had a third phase, where parallel or provisional governments were set up to govern during the rebellion. These alternative administrations were formed in areas like Ballia, Tamluk, and Satara. The movement helped India eventually gain independence in 1947.

question: Who among the following led the Sepoys at Kanpur in the 1857 uprising? (UPSC Prelims 1990)
option_1: Tantia Tope
option_2: Laxmibai
option_3: Nana Sahib
option_4: Kunwar Singh
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • Nana Sahib led the revolt of 1857 in Kanpur.He was the 14th Peshwa of the Maratha Empire, and his original name was Dhondu Pant. Nana Sahib joined the revolt after being denied pension and honors because he was not the natural born heir. Tantia Tope, Nana Sahib’s general, assisted him in Kanpur.
  • The revolt began in Meerut on May 10, 1857, and gradually spread to places like Kanpur, Bareilly, Jhansi, Delhi, and Awadh. On June 23, 1857, rebel soldiers under Nana Sahib launched a major attack on the British entrenchment.

The Indian Rebellion of 1857 :

  • It was a major but unsuccessful uprising against the British East India Company’s rule in India from 1857–58. The revolt began on May 10, 1857, at Meerut as a sepoy mutiny. The revolt is also known as the Sepoy Mutiny, the Indian Mutiny, the Great Rebellion, and the Revolt of 1857.
  • The revolt began as a mutiny of the British East India Company’s army sepoys, but eventually gained the support of the masses. The immediate cause of the revolt was the introduction of new Enfield cartridges, which were rumored to be lined with cow and pig fat. Both Hindus and Muslims had issues with pig and cow fat.
  • The revolt was a failure due to poor organization and lack of mass support. The sepoys lacked a common ideal, and it was difficult to find a leader with both military and political skills.
  • The revolt resulted in the deaths of over 50,000 sepoys, and another 100,000 civilians killed by the British. The chaos that followed also contributed to a major famine that killed even more people.

question: The Second Round Table Conference was held in........... (UPSC Prelims 1990)
option_1: 1930
option_2: 1931
option_3: 1932
option_4: 1935
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • The Second Round Table Conference was held from September to December 1931, after the signing of the Gandhi–Irwin Pact, which brought the Civil Disobedience Movement to a temporary halt. Mahatma Gandhi attended this conference as the sole representative of the Indian National Congress. The discussions focused on constitutional reforms, the communal question, and representation of minorities.
  • However, sharp differences arose between Gandhi and leaders like Muhammad Ali Jinnah of the Muslim League, as well as the representatives of the depressed classes led by Dr. B. R. Ambedkar.
  • Gandhi opposed the idea of separate electorates for minorities, which led to an impasse. Consequently, this conference too ended without success.

question: The most effective contribution made by Dadabhai Nauroji to the cause of Indian National Movement was that he............. (UPSC Prelims 1990)
option_1: Brought the problems of Indians to the notice of the British
option_2: Exposed the economic exploitation of India by the British
option_3: Interpreted the ancient Indian texts and restored the self-confidence of Indians
option_4: Stressed the need for eradication of all the social evils before anything else
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • Dadabhai Naoroji’s most effective contribution to the Indian National Movement was his focus on economic issues.
  • Naoroji was an Indian political leader, scholar, merchant, and writer. He was a member of the British House of Commons as a Liberal Party Member of Parliament. He served as the 2nd, 9th, and 22nd President of the Indian National Congress from 1886 to 1887, 1893 to 1894, and 1906 to 1907.
  • In 1901, Naoroji published Poverty and Un-British Rule in India, which highlighted the economic exploitation of India by the British. His work on economic exploitation gave rise to the Indian nationalist movement. His famous Drain Theory explained how India’s wealth was being drained to England through various means.

question: “The Modern Review’ was started by............. (UPSC Prelims 1990)
option_1: Madan Mohan Malaviya
option_2: C. V. Chintamani
option_3: Ramanand Chatterjee
option_4: Annie Besant
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • Ramananda Chatterjee (1865 - 1943) founded The Modern Review in 1907. The monthly magazine was published in Calcutta from 1907 to 1995. Chatterjeealso edited the magazine, and is sometimes called the “Father of Indian Journalism”.
  • The magazine covered essays on politics, economics, and society, as well as poems, stories, travelogues, and sketches. It also included illustrations by notable Bengali artists of the time.
  • Chatterjee also founded and edited the Bengali magazine Prabasi and the Hindi magazine Vishal Bharat.

question:
Assertion (A): Ali Brothers founded the Swaraj Party.

Reason (R): The Swarajists were in favour of council entry and obstruction from within. (UPSC Prelims 1990)
option_1: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
option_2: Both A and R are true but R is not a correct explanation of A
option_3: A is true but R is false.
option_4: A is false but R is true.
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • The Ali brothers, Shaukat Ali and Mohammad Ali Jauhar, founded the Khilafat Movement in 1919. The movement was a protest against the British government and the injustice done to Turkey. The movement was an agitation by Indian Muslims and Indian nationalists to pressure the British government to preserve the authority of the Ottoman Sultan as Caliph of Islam after World War I. The movement was supported by Mahatma Gandhi and the Indian National Congress.
  • The Ali brothers were also influential Muslim leaders in British India who fought for independence. In 1913, Muhammad Ali Jauhar launched the daily publication Hamdard to express his dissent against imperial rule. The Ali brothers also founded newspapers that spread their political messages and worked to expand Aligarh Muslim University.
  • The Swaraj Party was founded in 1923 by Motilal Nehru and C.R. Das. The party’s policy was to win elections to the CentralLegislative Assembly and obstruct its proceedings from within.
  • The Swarajists, also known as the pro changers, wanted to enter the legislative council and obstruct the British government from within. In the 1923 elections, many candidates of the Swaraj Party were elected to the central legislative assembly and provincial legislative council.
  • Another school of thought, led by Vallabhbhai Patel, R Prasad, Rajaji, and M.A. Ansari, came to be known as the “No changers”. The “No-changers” opposed council entry.

question: When the Portuguese arrived in India, the foreigners whom they encountered as trade rivals were the............. (UPSC Prelims 1991)
option_1: Persians
option_2: Arabs
option_3: Dutch
option_4: English
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • When the Portuguese arrived in India, they encountered the Arabs as trade rivals. The Portuguese tried to break the Arab monopoly on the Indian spice trade. After 20 years of conflict, the Portuguese succeeded.
  • The Portuguese came to India to establish a monopoly over the spice trade. At the time, the Ottoman Turks and the Arabs dominated the spice trade. Spice was a valuable commodity because it preserved food during the harsh European winters.
  • The Portuguese India armada was the main carrier of the spice trade between Europe and Asia during the 16th century. The Portuguese monopoly on the Cape route lasted for a century, until it was broken by Dutch and English competition in the early 1600s.

question: The intensity of famine increased in India under the British rule because............. (UPSC Prelims 1991)
option_1: The failure of monsoons became frequent
option_2: The drain of wealth from India was uncontrolled
option_3: Of the poor distribution of food grains
option_4: Discriminatory protection was extended, to food processing industries
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

 The intensity of famine increased in India under British rule due to a combination of factors: British economic and administrative policies:

These included:

1. Rack-renting

2. Levies for war

3. Free trade policies

4. Expansion of export agriculture

5. Neglect of agricultural investment

6. Extraction of land revenue

7. Conversion of agricultural land for cash crops

8. Disruption of traditional agricultural practices

9. Imposition of high taxes

10. Uneven rainfall

11. Drought

12. Continuous draining of India’s wealth

  • The British administration took over in 1858 and became concerned with preventing famines. The Famine Commission Report of 1880 recommended the introduction of Famine Codes. However, before these measures had an effect, two more famines followed.
  • The famines in nineteenth-century India were often caused by massive crop failures resulting from drought. The first effect of drought was to stop all field labor, which threw people out of work. This led to distress among agricultural laborers and rural artisans, and the few small trades and handicrafts that depended on them.
  • The proximate cause of famines, without exception, was a sharp rise in food prices, which in turn reduced real wages and caused starvation, malnutrition and epidemic, mainly among agricultural labourer groups.

What is Drain Of Wealth?

  • Dadabhai Naoroji wrote Poverty and Un British Rule in India in 1901. The book is a study of the difference between British liberal ideas and the reality of British rule in India.
  • In the book, Naoroji criticizes the economic impact of British rule and argues that British economic policies extracted wealth from India to finance Britain’s industries. This theory is known as the “drain of wealth”. Naoroji also argues that British rule was despotic and destructive to Indians.
  • Naoroji was a former Liberal member of parliament, founder and some-time president of the Indian National Congress, and merchant. At the time of writing he was living in Britain.

question: Which one of the following is the most significant contribution of Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel to modern India? (UPSC Prelims 1991)

option_2: His role in the Non Cooperation Movement
option_3: His achievement of the integration of princely states
option_4: His Presidentship of the Indian National Congress
solution_text:

  • Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel’s integration of 565 princely states into the Union of India is considered his most significant contribution to modern India.
  • Patel was the first Home Minister of independent India and played a key role in integrating the princely states into the Indian federation.
  • A princely state was a nominally sovereign entity of the British Indian Empire, but was not directly governed by the British.
  • At the time of British withdrawal in 1947, princely states covered 40% of the area of pre-independence India and constituted 23% of its population.

question:
Consider the following two statements called Assertion (A) and Reason (R) and answer by using the codes given below the statements. (UPSC Prelims 1991)

  • It was a political movement led by Mahatma Gandhi and the Indian National Congress that began on August 8, 1942. The movement’s goal was to force the British government to quit India immediately.

The movement had several causes, including:

1. The attitude of the British government

2. Growing nationalism

3. Socio-economic factors

4. The defeat of the British in World War II

The movement had two phases:

2. Quasi-guerrilla insurgency phase: After September 1942

  • The movement resulted in widespread civil disobedience and protests, which were met with harsh repression by the British authorities.

question: On whose recommendation was the Constituent Assembly formed? (UPSC Prelims 1991)

option_3: Cabinet Mission Plan
option_4: Government of India Act, 1935

  • The Constituent Assembly of India was formed in 1946 on the recommendations of the Cabinet Mission. The idea of a constituent assembly was first proposed in 1934 by M.N. Roy.
  • The Constituent Assembly’s main goal was to draft the Constitution of India. The Constitution was implemented on May 16, 1946.

question: Federation, Indian responsibility, reservation and safeguards were the three lynchpins of............. (UPSC Prelims 1991)

  • The pact aimed to resolve the civil disobedience movement and ease political tensions in India.

The pact made the British government concede some demands, including:

1. Withdrawing all ordinances and prosecutions

2. Releasing all political prisoners

3. Restoring the confiscated properties of the satyagrahis

4. Permitting the free collection or manufacture of salt

  • The pact temporarily terminated the Civil Disobedience Movement and the Congress decided to take part in the Second Round Table Conference.

question: “I have nothing to offer but blood, toil, tears and sweat.” Who said this? (UPSC Prelims 1991)
option_1: Winston Churchill
option_2: Jawaharlal Nehru
option_3: Mahatma Gandhi
option_4: Mao Tse-Tunq

  • Churchill said this when he met with his Cabinet on May 13, 1940, and later when he asked the House of Commons for a vote of confidence in his new government.
  • In the speech, Churchill uses powerful words and maintains a serious tone to show the citizens of his country how important the war is and how the only choice they have is victory.
  • Churchill was the Conservative Prime Minister of Britain from 1940 to 1945 and again from 1951 to 1955.

question: “English men are more efficient partly by upbringing, partly by race and partly by education”. Who said this? (UPSC Prelims 1991)

question:

  3.

P. C. Joshi
